thread.title: K-State can’t hold Boykin late in loss
thread.title_full: K-State can’t hold Boykin late in loss

title: K-State can’t hold Boykin late in loss
text:
RELATED ARTICLE Wildcats bracing for juggernaut Horned Frogs offense Boasting one of the nation’s top offenses and an early season Heisman candidate in Trevone Boykin, TCU is about to serve up the biggest challenge Kansas State’s defense has seen this season. 
For three quarters on Saturday night, the Kansas State football team looked like it figured out how to contain TCU quarterback Trevone Boykin. 
At the start of the fourth quarter, the Wildcats had a 35-31 lead and were once again moving the ball in the TCU red zone, playing keep away from the Horned Frogs’ signal caller by engineering long drives on offense and coming up with a pair of interceptions. 
But things changed quickly. 
The Horned Frogs put together an 11-play, 70-yard touchdown drive to cut the K-State lead to five. 
On the next possession, Boykin was able to do his thing against a worn-out K-State defense, breaking off a 69-yard touchdown to give TCU its first lead of the game at 45-42. 
After K-State answered with a 37-yard game-tying field goal and only 1:47 left on the clock, Boykin took to the air, completing a 55-yard pass to Josh Doctson to regain the lead and put away the win. 
“He’s as talented an athlete as you’ll find,” K-State head coach Bill Snyder said. “He proved it tonight and he proves it every time he plays.” 
In the first three quarters, the K-State defense held the Heisman Trophy candidate to just 18 yards rushing and 214 yards passing, with two interceptions. By the end of the night, however, he had amassed 124 yards on the ground and 301 through the air. 
Defensive end Jordan Willis said the defense was disappointed after allowing the two long scoring plays late in the game. 
“It’s frustrating because it’s been two weeks now that we needed to make a stop on defense and we didn’t make it happen,” Willis said. “Then they get those big plays - the long pass to Doctson and the zone read — those are kind of heartbreaking because you need to make them earn that touchdown, and we just gave that to them. That hurts, but in the end you have to deal with it and move on to the next game.” 
In addition to containing Boykin and his running attack, the Wildcats benefited from a pair of turnovers caused by linebacker Elijah Lee. 
After playing almost exclusively as a situational pass rusher last year as a true freshman, Lee transitioned into an every-down role this season and happened to be in the right place twice to pick off Boykin. 
The first came in the second quarter and led to a K-State touchdown four plays later that gave the Wildcats a 28-17 lead. 
The second pick came in the third quarter as Boykin threw low and missed his receiver, with Lee getting under the ball. K-State didn’t score following the turnover, but did pin the Horned Frogs at their own 10-yard line after a three-and-out. 
Snyder said the turnovers were much needed. 
“He reacted well — that was a key element,” he said. “One of them was a poor throw and he did a nice job. I’m proud of him, I know that.” 
The pick in the second quarter was Lee’s first career interception. 
“It’s very tough to prepare for a guy like that,” Lee said of Boykin. “You never know if he’ll take off or throw the ball. To get two picks off of him was nice, but at the end of the day we lost, so those two picks don’t really mean anything at this point in time.”
